title: EcoCleanR: Overview on Steps for Data cleaning and defining Biogeographic ranges
text: tutorial, demonstrate step--step process cleaning occurrences extracting environmental data coastal species Mexacanthina lugubris. workflow covers data Cleaning:  1. Remove duplicates 2. Check bad taxon using WoRMs 3. Improve coordinate information utilizing external georeference tools 4. check coordinate precision rounding 5. Flag records associated wrong ocean/sea inland 6. Extract environmental variables 7. Impute environmental variables assignment online resources 8. Identifying outliers 9. Data visualization:  demonstration steps: Note: details data integration, see [data_merging]
code: # package loading library(EcoCleanR) library(dplyr) # provide example species name species_name <- "Mexacanthina lugubris"

title: EcoCleanR: Overview on Steps for Data cleaning and defining Biogeographic ranges
text: Remove duplicates merged dataset product merging data various sources ec_rm_duplicate return occurrence table “ecodata” removing duplicates based unique catalog numbers, retaining abundance counts wherever available.
code: ecodata <- ec_rm_duplicate(Mixdb.occ, catalogNumber = "catalogNumber", abundance = "abundance") str(ecodata[,1:3])  ### Optional to perform: check the institution code # inst_counts <- ecodata %>% # group_by(institutionCode) %>% # summarise(record_count = n(), .groups = "drop")  ### optional to perform.. # ecodata <- ecodata %>% # filter(is.na(institutionCode) | institutionCode != "NRM") ec_geographic_map(ecodata,   latitude = "decimalLatitude",   longitude = "decimalLongitude" )

title: EcoCleanR: Overview on Steps for Data cleaning and defining Biogeographic ranges
text: step helps check wrong taxonomy fetched online datasources checking accepted synonym WoRMS (World Register Marine Species) taxonomy database ec_worms_synonym returns table named comparison two columns: first column lists synonyms accepted WoRMS database, second column lists unique species names ecodata counts occurrences
code: comparison <- ec_worms_synonym(species_name,   ecodata,   scientificName = "scientificName" ) print(comparison) # compare the columns to know if any taxa found that is not a synonym in WoRMS data base, filter bad taxa from ecodata using dplyr::filter()

title: EcoCleanR: Overview on Steps for Data cleaning and defining Biogeographic ranges
text: step generates table “data_need_correction” can potentially assign georeferences based locality verbatim locality information occurrence table using furntion ec_flag_with_locality. table can used input file GEOLocate tool perform georeferencing. Currently, R code available automate process. process require manual validation records assigned coordinates uncertainty. (see Scenario B manuscript example) Use ec_merge_coorected_Coordinates assigned corrected coordinates - latitude, longitude coordinte uncertainty, back main data table. Pre-saved data file ecodata_corrected.rda, example use template.
code: ecodata$flag_check_geolocate <- ec_flag_with_locality(ecodata,   uncertainty = "coordinateUncertaintyInMeters",   locality = "locality",   verbatimLocality = "verbatimLocality" ) str(ecodata[,1:3]) data_need_correction <- ecodata %>% filter(flag_check_geolocate!= 1) #save the data as local file to insert in GEOLocate web tool #write.csv(data_need_correction, "data_check_geolocate.csv")  #Load back the corrected coordinate file extracted from GEOLocate  #ecodata_corrected <- read.csv("M lugubris_corrected_geolocate.csv")  ### Merged records with improved georeference: ecodata <- ec_merge_corrected_coordinates(   ecodata_corrected,    ecodata,    latitude = "decimalLatitude",    longitude = "decimalLongitude",          uncertainty_col = "coordinateUncertaintyInMeters" ) str(ecodata[,1:3])   ### Plot the map to visualize the datapoints ec_geographic_map(ecodata, latitude = "decimalLatitude", longitude = "decimalLongitude")

title: EcoCleanR: Overview on Steps for Data cleaning and defining Biogeographic ranges
text: ec_filter_by_uncertainty function can used scenarios (see manuscript) help remove extremely high uncertainty remaining data.
code: ecodata_cl <- ec_filter_by_uncertainty(ecodata,   uncertainty_col = "coordinateUncertaintyInMeters",   percentile = 0.95,   ask = FALSE,   latitude = "decimalLatitude",   longitude = "decimalLongitude" ) str(ecodata_cl[, 1:3]) ### plot the map ec_geographic_map(ecodata_cl,   latitude = "decimalLatitude",   longitude = "decimalLongitude" )

title: EcoCleanR: Overview on Steps for Data cleaning and defining Biogeographic ranges
text: ec_flag_precision checks precision coordinates. function flags records based two checkpoints: 1) flag coordinates independently <2 decimal points; 2) check rounding nearest 0.5° either coordinates.
code: ecodata_cl$flag_precision <- ec_flag_precision(ecodata_cl,   latitude = "decimalLatitude",   longitude = "decimalLongitude" )  # filter the flag - flag_cordinate_precision ecodata_cl <- ecodata_cl %>%   filter(flag_precision != 1) str(ecodata_cl[1:3])

what: Step6: Records tagged to wrong ocean/sea
title: EcoCleanR: Overview on Steps for Data cleaning and defining Biogeographic ranges
text: ec_flag_non_region function helps identify records incorrectly tagged wrong ocean sea. Expert knowledge required recognize species unlikely occur certain ocean regions. example, Mexacanthina lugubris Eastern Pacific species; therefore, occurrences reported Atlantic Ocean flagged running function.  Variables “direction” accepts input “east” “west”, variable “ocean” accepts input “atlantic” “pacific”.  given species lives globally, cleaning step needed.
code: # This is a heavy processing step, won’t execute during vignette building. direction <- "east" buffer <- 25000 ocean <- "pacific" ecodata_cl$flag_non_region <- ec_flag_non_region(direction,   ocean,   buffer,   ecodata_cl,   latitude = "decimalLatitude",   longitude = "decimalLongitude" ) str(ecodata_cl[, 1:3]) # filter flagged records ecodata_cl <- ecodata_cl %>%   filter(flag_non_region != 1) ### map view to see accepted records ec_geographic_map(ecodata_cl,   latitude = "decimalLatitude",   longitude = "decimalLongitude" )

title: EcoCleanR: Overview on Steps for Data cleaning and defining Biogeographic ranges
text: ec_extract_env_layers function extracts environmental data occurrence points using associated coordinates. designed ‘sdmpredictors’ package extract layers sources Bio-ORACLE, MARSPEC, WorldClim. ec_impute_env_values imputes environmental data coordinates lacking values environmental data sources. provide average value existing data within input radius.
code: # This is a heavy processing step, won’t execute during vignette building. # get the unique combination of coordiantes ecodata_unique <- ecodata_cl[, c("decimalLatitude", "decimalLongitude")] ecodata_unique <- base::unique(ecodata_unique) # It is recommended to check what layers available in sdm_predictors and correct name. # available_layers <- list_layers() # returns something like c("BO_sstmean", "BO_sstmax", ...) # provide layers as input to env_layers variable env_layers <- c("BO_sstmean", "BO_sstmin", "BO_sstmax")  ### extraction env layers ecodata_unique <- ec_extract_env_layers(ecodata_unique,   env_layers = env_layers,   latitude = "decimalLatitude",   longitude = "decimalLongitude" ) # A warning message if layers are in saved in cache.  ### impute env var values those were missing after extraction ecodata_unique <- ec_impute_env_values(   ecodata_unique,   latitude = "decimalLatitude",   longitude = "decimalLongitude",   radius_km = 10,   iter = 3 )  ### omit the coordinate which couldn't get any env values after imputation ecodata_unique <- na.omit(ecodata_unique)

title: EcoCleanR: Overview on Steps for Data cleaning and defining Biogeographic ranges
text: ec_flag_outlier function helps identify outliers based spatial (coordinates) non-spatial (environmental) attributes. (see manuscript detail function)
code: # This is a heavy processing step, won’t execute during vignette building. # Instead of executing it here, we will use a pre-saved cleaned file. ecodata_unique$flag_outliers <- ec_flag_outlier(ecodata_unique,   latitude = "decimalLatitude",   longitude = "decimalLongitude",   env_layers,   itr = 50,   k = 3,   geo_quantile = 0.99,   maha_quantile = 0.99 )$outlier  ### these unique combinations of coordiantes, environmental variables and outliers will be mergeed to main ecodata_cl file ecodata_cl <- ecodata_cl %>%   left_join(ecodata_unique[, c("decimalLatitude", "decimalLongitude", "flag_outliers", env_layers)],     by = c("decimalLatitude", "decimalLongitude")   ) # pre-saved file ecodata_with_outliers instead of using ecodata_cl ### map view to see records with outlier probability ec_geographic_map_w_flag(ecodata_with_outliers,   flag_column = "outliers",   latitude = "decimalLatitude",   longitude = "decimalLongitude" ) ### Filter outliers those have higher outlier probability >0.90, 0.95 etc. ecodata_cleaned <- ecodata_cl %>%   filter(flag_outliers < 0.95) ### mapview to visualize accepted data ec_geographic_map(ecodata_cleaned,   latitude = "decimalLatitude",   longitude = "decimalLongitude" )

what: Step9: Display final accepted biogeographic range
title: EcoCleanR: Overview on Steps for Data cleaning and defining Biogeographic ranges
text: ec_var_summary generates summary table accepted occurrences data cleaning, showing mean, minimum, maximum values spatial non-spatial attributes. ec_plot_var_range shows plot accepted ranges. documents: *see data merging vignette: [data_merging] *see citation guidelines downloaded files gbif, obis, idigbio InvertEbase vignettes/article/cite_data.rmd
code: env_layers <- c("BO_sstmean", "BO_sstmax", "BO_sstmin") data("ecodata_cleaned") summary_table <- ec_var_summary(ecodata_cleaned,   latitude = "decimalLatitude",   longitude = "decimalLongitude",   env_layers ) head(summary_table)  ec_plot_var_range(ecodata_with_outliers,   summary_df = summary_table,   latitude = "decimalLatitude",   longitude = "decimalLongitude",   env_layers = env_layers )

title: EcoCleanR: Overview on Steps for Data merging from online bioiversity resources
text: tutorial, demonstrate step--step process downloading data various sources GBIF, OBIS, iDigBio using existing R packages, well InvertEbase via local CSV file. process includes merging data files standardizing formats make compatible integration. Example species: Mexacanthina lugubris

title: EcoCleanR: Overview on Steps for Data merging from online bioiversity resources
code: library(EcoCleanR) library(rgbif) library(robis) library(ridigbio) library(dplyr)

title: EcoCleanR: Overview on Steps for Data merging from online bioiversity resources
code: species_name <- "Mexacanthina lugubris" taxonkey <- name_backbone(species_name)$usageKey

what: Create a attribute list with TDWG standardize names
title: EcoCleanR: Overview on Steps for Data merging from online bioiversity resources
text: Given attributes list can changed/added based requirement
code: attribute_list <- c("source", "catalogNumber", "basisOfRecord", "occurrenceStatus", "institutionCode", "verbatimEventDate", "scientificName", "individualCount", "organismQuantity", "abundance", "decimalLatitude", "decimalLongitude", "coordinateUncertaintyInMeters", "locality", "verbatimLocality", "municipality", "county", "stateProvince", "country", "countryCode")

title: EcoCleanR: Overview on Steps for Data merging from online bioiversity resources
text: step uses function occ_data rgbif package extract data GBIF.
code: gbif.occ <- occ_data(taxonKey = taxonkey, occurrenceStatus = NULL, limit = 10000L)$data  # refer article/cite_data.Rmd for instructions on how to cite the data from gbif- data providers  ## additional field added to know the source gbif.occ$source <- "gbif" for (field in attribute_list) {   if (!field %in% names(gbif.occ)) {     gbif.occ[[field]] <- NA # Add the missing field as NA   } }  ## we are making one column called abundance which should have values from individual count and organism Quantity gbif.occ$abundance <- ifelse(is.na(as.numeric(gbif.occ$individualCount)), as.numeric(gbif.occ$organismQuantity), as.numeric(gbif.occ$individualCount)) ## additional field added to know the source gbif.occ$source <- "gbif" gbif.occ_temp <- gbif.occ[, attribute_list] str(gbif.occ_temp[, 1:3])

title: EcoCleanR: Overview on Steps for Data merging from online bioiversity resources
text: step uses occurrence function robis package extract data OBIS.
code: obis.occ <- occurrence(species_name) for (field in attribute_list) {   if (!field %in% names(obis.occ)) {     obis.occ[[field]] <- NA # Add the missing field as NA   } } obis.occ$abundance <- ifelse(is.na(as.numeric(obis.occ$individualCount)), as.numeric(obis.occ$organismQuantity), as.numeric(obis.occ$individualCount)) obis.occ$source <- "obis" obis.occ$municipality <- "" obis.occ_temp <- obis.occ[, attribute_list] str(obis.occ_temp[, 1:3])

title: EcoCleanR: Overview on Steps for Data merging from online bioiversity resources
text: step uses idig_search_records ridigbio package extract data IDIGBIO.
code: idig.occ <- idig_search_records(   type = "records",   rq = list("scientificname" = species_name),   field = "all",   max_items = 10000L,   limit = 10000L,   offset = 0 )  idig.occ <- idig.occ %>%   mutate(     abundance = as.numeric(individualcount),     source = "idigbio",     occurrenceStatus = "",     organismQuantity = ""   ) %>%   rename(     decimalLatitude = geopoint.lat,     decimalLongitude = geopoint.lon,     basisOfRecord = basisofrecord,     catalogNumber = catalognumber,     scientificName = scientificname,     stateProvince = stateprovince,     coordinateUncertaintyInMeters = coordinateuncertainty,     individualCount = individualcount,     institutionCode = institutioncode,     verbatimLocality = verbatimlocality,     verbatimEventDate = verbatimeventdate,     countryCode = countrycode   )  idig.occ_temp <- idig.occ[, attribute_list] str(idig.occ_temp[, 1:3])

what: Local file (InvertEbase) - data read and standardization
title: EcoCleanR: Overview on Steps for Data merging from online bioiversity resources
text: local file “example_sp_invertebase” manual downloaded file InvertEbase Mexacanthina lugubris. See example_sp_invertEbase dataset attributes DwC format.
code: sym.occ <- example_sp_invertebase sym.occ$abundance <- as.numeric(sym.occ$individualCount)  for (field in attribute_list) {   if (!field %in% names(sym.occ)) {     sym.occ[[field]] <- NA # Add the missing field as NA   } }  str(sym.occ[, 1:3])

title: EcoCleanR: Overview on Steps for Data merging from online bioiversity resources
text: ec_db_merge function EcoCleanR package helps merge data sources, provided source attribute names number columns. also filters data based specified type (e.g., modern fossil) removes records marked ‘absent’ occurrenceStatus. documents: *see data cleaning steps mixdb (merged) dataset vignette: [data_cleaning] *see citation guidelines downloaded files gbif, obis, idigbio InvertEbase vignettes/article/cite_data.rmd
code: db_list <- list(gbif.occ_temp, obis.occ_temp, idig.occ_temp, sym.occ) Mixdb.occ <- ec_db_merge(db_list = db_list, datatype = "modern")  str(Mixdb.occ[, 1:3]) ec_geographic_map(Mixdb.occ, "decimalLatitude", longitude = "decimalLongitude") # display records those has coordinate values

what: EcoCleanR: Enhancing Data Quality of Biogeographic Ranges with Application for Marine Invertebrates
title: EcoCleanR: Enhancing Data Quality of Biogeographic Ranges with Application for Marine Invertebrates
text: goal EcoCleanR provides functions integrate biodiversity data multiple aggregates offers step--step framework data cleaning, outlier detection, generation species biogeographic ranges. also supports extraction relevant environmental information assist ecological conservation analyses. Key features: Data Merging: Merge data GBIF (rgbif), iDigBio (ridigbio), OBIS (robis) local input data file (e.g. used csv file downloaded InvertEBase database). Data Cleaning:  2.1. Remove duplicates 2.2. Check bad taxon using WoRMs 2.3. Improve coordinate information utilizing external georeference tools 2.4. check coordinate precision rounding 2.5. Flag records associated wrong ocean/sea inland 2.6. Extract environmental variables 2.7. Impute environmental variables assignment online resources 2.8. Identifying outliers Data visualization:  3.1. Create map view 3.2. Execute summary table max, min mean limits variables 3.3. Create summary plot represent suitable range species spatial non spatial attributes

title: EcoCleanR: Enhancing Data Quality of Biogeographic Ranges with Application for Marine Invertebrates
text: basic example demonstrate data processing, merging cleanings steps species name “Mexacanthina lugubris”     documents: *see data merging vignette: [data_merging] *see data cleaning steps merged dataset vignette: [data_cleaning] *see Step--Step Workflow vignette detailed explanation complete process — data downloading merging, cleaning, visualization vignettes/article/stepbystep.rmd. *see citation guidelines downloaded data gbif, obis, idigbio InvertEbase [cite_data] vignettes/article/cite_data.rmd.
code: library(EcoCleanR) ## basic example code # After execution of step 1 and 2.1, output file called "ecodata" # This dataset contains ~1100 occurrence records for the species Mexacanthina lugubris. It was compiled by merging data from multiple online repositories — GBIF, OBIS, iDigBio and local file (InvertEbase) — consider as step 1 (Vignette: data_merging). Duplicate records were removed to retain only unique occurrences (2.1) using function "ec_rm_duplicate". # The algorithm for these steps can be found on article folder - documentation head(ecodata) #> ec_geographic_map(ecodata,   latitude = "decimalLatitude",   longitude = "decimalLongitude" ) #> Warning: Removed 358 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range #> (`geom_point()`). # lets execute cleaning steps # step 2.2 - check taxon error for species name - "Mexacanthina lugubris" comparison <- ec_worms_synonym(   "Mexacanthina lugubris",   ecodata,   scientificName = "scientificName" ) #> ══  1 queries  ═══════════════ #>  #> Retrieving data for taxon 'Mexacanthina lugubris' #> ✔  Found:  Mexacanthina lugubris #> ══  Results  ═════════════════ #>  #> • Total: 1  #> • Found: 1  #> • Not Found: 0 # step 2.3 - check records with locality but no coordinate assignments ecodata$flag_with_locality <- ec_flag_with_locality(   ecodata,   uncertainty = "coordinateUncertaintyInMeters",   locality = "locality",   verbatimLocality = "verbatimLocality" ) # upload back the corrected file with csv upload - name it as ecodata_corrected head(ecodata_corrected) #>   cleaned_catalog corrected_latitude corrected_longitude corrected_uncertainty #> 1            1001           29.03741           -118.3182                 19180 #> 2            1016           29.03741           -118.3182                 19180 #> 3       102443960           32.72160           -117.2112                 23582 #> 4       104087711           32.66767           -117.2452                  1771 #> 5       104911613           32.72160           -117.2112                 23284 #> 6       105885508           32.83330           -117.2667                  2962 ecodata <- ec_merge_corrected_coordinates(   ecodata_corrected,   ecodata,   latitude = "decimalLatitude",   longitude = "decimalLongitude",   uncertainty_col = "coordinateUncertaintyInMeters" )  ecodata <- ec_filter_by_uncertainty(   ecodata,   uncertainty_col = "coordinateUncertaintyInMeters",   percentile = 0.95,   ask = TRUE,   latitude = "decimalLatitude",   longitude = "decimalLongitude" ) #> Suggested threshold at 95th percentile: 24015.45 #> Do you want to apply this threshold? (y/n): #> No filtering applied.  # step 2.4 - check records with bad precision <2 as well as rounding issue ecodata$flag_precision <- ec_flag_precision(   ecodata,   latitude = "decimalLatitude",   longitude = "decimalLongitude" ) # step 2.5 - check records with wrong assignment of ocean/sea and inland with certain buffer range - not executing on run if (FALSE) {   ecodata$flag_non_region <- ec_flag_non_region(     "east",     "pacific",     buffer = 25000,     ecodata,     latitude = "decimalLatitude",     longitude = "decimalLongitude"   ) } # step 2.6 - extract the environmental variables, here we are using a data table which has unique combination of coordinates - we call it ecodata_x - not executing on run if (FALSE) {   env_layers <- c("BO_sstmean", "BO_sstmax", "BO_sstmin")   ecodata_x <- ec_extract_env_layers(ecodata_x,     env_layers = env_layers,     latitude = "decimalLatitude",     longitude = "decimalLongitude"   ) } # step 2.7 - impute the environmental variables for those coordinates with no assignment on online data sources. if (FALSE) {   ecodata_x <- ec_impute_env_values(ecodata_x, radius_km, iter) } # step 2.8 - calculate outlier probability for each data points. if (FALSE) {   ecodata_x$flag_outliers <- ((     ec_flag_outlier(       ecodata_x,       latitude = "decimalLatitude",       longitude = "decimalLongitude",       env_layers,       itr = 100,       k = 3,       geo_quantile = 0.99,       maha_quantile = 0.99   )))$ouliers } # step 3.1 - visualize the map with outlier probability index, bind the ecodata_x with ecodata with updated column flag_outlier ec_geographic_map_w_flag(   ecodata_with_outliers,   flag_column = "outliers",   latitude = "decimalLatitude",   longitude = "decimalLongitude" ) #> Ignoring unknown labels: #> • colour : "Flag" # at this stage we can decide the acceptable outlier probability and after removing higher probable a new datafram called ecodata_cleaned can be source of summary table (next step) # step 3.2 - Visualize the summary table env_layers <- c("BO_sstmean", "BO_sstmax", "BO_sstmin") data("ecodata_cleaned") ec_geographic_map(ecodata_cleaned) summary_table <- ec_var_summary(   ecodata_cleaned,   latitude = "decimalLatitude",   longitude = "decimalLongitude",   env_layers ) print(summary_table) #>           variable     Max     Min    Mean #> 1  decimalLatitude   34.04   22.92   31.73 #> 2 decimalLongitude -106.10 -118.94 -116.58 #> 3       BO_sstmean   29.04   16.15   17.97 #> 4        BO_sstmax   32.68   18.79   22.47 #> 5        BO_sstmin   24.96   11.42   14.41 # step 3.3 - Plot to visual the acceptable limit of a species which demonstrate a suitable habitat range: ec_plot_var_range(   ecodata_with_outliers,   summary_table,   latitude = "decimalLatitude",   longitude = "decimalLongitude",   env_layers )

code: data <- data.frame(   scientificName = "Mexacanthina lugubris",   decimalLongitude = c(-117, -117.8, -116.9, -116.5),   decimalLatitude = c(32.9, 33.5, 31.9, 32.4),   temperature_mean = c(12, 13, 14, 11),   temperature_min = c(9, 6, 10, 10),   temperature_max = c(14, 16, 18, 17),   flag_outlier = c(0, 0.5, 1, 0.7) ) # this data table has data points which was considered as outliers  data_x <- data.frame(   scientificName = "Mexacanthina lugubris",   decimalLongitude = c(-117, -117.8, -116.5),   decimalLatitude = c(32.9, 33.5, 32.4),   temperature_mean = c(12, 13, 11),   temperature_min = c(9, 6, 10),   temperature_max = c(14, 16, 17),   flag_outlier = c(0, 0.5, 0.7) ) # cleaned data base after removing outliers >x probability. # in this example, removed data points >0.7 probability to be # considering outliers   env_layers <- c("temperature_mean", "temperature_min", "temperature_max") summary_df <- ec_var_summary(data_x,   latitude = "decimalLatitude",   longitude = "decimalLongitude",   env_layers ) # this is the final cleaned data table which # will be used to derive summary of acceptable niche  ec_plot_var_range(data,   summary_df,   latitude = "decimalLatitude",   longitude = "decimalLongitude",   env_layers )

title: EcoCleanR 1.0.2
text: -submission updates version 1.0.1, archived due internet access R CMD check. version, internet-dependent workflows (e.g. WoRMS/geodata maps/Bio-Oracle layers) removed examples tests wrapped \dontrun{} guarded internet access occurs CRAN checks. package now passes R CMD check without internet use. Metadata issues noted archived version also corrected. - Fixed Authors@R metadata documentation issues. - Resolved CRAN check warnings related undocumented objects. - Added dontrun functions dependency heavy download file resources. e.g. Marine environmental layers geographic maps.
